title-group.article-title: Projections of cancer mortality risks using spatio-temporal P-spline models

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Statistics and O. R., Public University of Navarre, Spain
2Consortium for Biomedical Research in Epidemiology and Public Health (CIBERESP), Spain

author-notes.corresp: María Dolores Ugarte, Departamento de Estadística e Investigación Operativa, Universidad Pública de Navarra, Campus de Arrosadía, 31006 Pamplona, Spain. Email: lola@unavarra.es

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Cancer mortality risk estimates are essential for planning resource allocation and designing and evaluating cancer prevention and management strategies. However, mortality figures generally become available after a few years, making necessary to develop reliable procedures to provide current and near future mortality risks. In this work, a spatio-temporal P-spline model is used to provide predictions of mortality/incidence counts. The model is appropriate to capture smooth temporal trends and to predict cancer mortality/incidence counts in different regions for future years. The prediction mean squared error of the forecast values as well as an appropriate estimator are derived. Spanish prostate cancer mortality data in the period 1975–2008 will be used to illustrate results with a focus on cancer mortality forecasting in 2009–2011.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Cancer research has achieved important goals in recent years, but this disease is still a major public health concern in most countries and also in Spain. According to the Spanish Statistical Institute, cancer was the second leading cause of mortality in Spain in 2009 (27.3%). By gender, tumors were the first leading cause of mortality in males and the second leading cause in females after cardiovascular diseases. The overall cost of cancer including direct costs (diagnosis and treatment) and indirect costs (lost production for sick leave, permanent disability, and death before retirement age) has an important impact on health budget and on society in general. As an example, the estimated direct cost of cancer in Spain for the year 2002 was 3855 millions of euros.1 In United States, the cost of cancer has nearly doubled in the past twenty years.2 The National Institutes of Health estimate of the overall annual cost of cancer in 2010 is about $263.8 billions. The total cost is split up into $102.8 billion for direct medical costs (total of all health expenditures); $20.9 billion for indirect morbidity costs (cost of lost productivity due to illness); and $140.1 billion for indirect mortality costs (cost of lost productivity due to premature death).3 The cost is likely to increase due to the anticipated growth and aging of the US population. Hence, as the activities related to cancer (research, diagnosis, and treatment) are expensive, figures for planning public health programs and clinical services are very important.

Health agencies plan cancer prevention resources based on cancer mortality/incidence risk estimations available to date. However, these official numbers are usually at public disposal after 3 years because of the delay in the administrative procedure to create the registries. In this context, statistical procedures providing mortality/incidence risk predictions for different regions or health areas are very useful. Researchers may use cancer statistics to investigate for example the effect of cancer control planning and to characterize the heterogeneity of geographical areas.

Despite the great amount of research on spatio-temporal evolution of risks in disease mapping, the literature on spatio-temporal risks or counts forecasting is not very abundant. Most of the research on this topic does not include the spatial distribution of the diseases. Without being exhaustive, we mention here some work on the topic. Dyba and Hakulinen4 compare three different methods for predicting disease incidence with data from Turku (Finland). They consider a model with Poisson distribution for the observed cases and models with a normal distribution for incidence rates. These are temporal models that do not consider the spatial dimension. Using Bayesian age–period–cohort models, Knorr-Held and Rainer5 predict future death rates until the year 2010 separately for males and females using data from 1952 to 1996. However, the spatial dimension is not considered either. Congdon6 combines autoregressive and growth curve principles within a spatio-temporal forecasting framework. In the United States, Ghosh and Tiwari,7 consider short-term prediction models for the number of deaths due to common cancers. These authors provide predictions for the year 2003 based on data from 1978 to 2000. Using jointpoint regression models Malvezzi et al.8 present estimates of mortality for all cancers and for selected major cancer sites in the year 2011 in the whole European Union and in its six more populated countries. They use actual mortality data up to the most recent available year, which is between 2005 and 2007 for most EU countries. The authors obtain results separately for each country but they do not consider spatial models. A different work including the spatial component corresponds to Schmid and Held,9 where time trends in cancer are extrapolated using Bayesian cohort models. Within a different class of models, Clements et al.10 consider age-period-cohort models with two-dimensional smoothing splines for age and period to predict lung cancer rates. The models are applied to data from five countries but no spatial analysis is conducted.

In this work a spatio-temporal P-spline model including space–time interactions is considered for smoothing and forecasting cancer mortality risks by regions within a country. Alternative space–time disease mapping models have been considered by other authors (see for example, Lawson et al.11). P-splines with B-spline bases have been popularized by Eilers and Marx12 and their use has increased during the last few years due to their useful properties. They are very flexible and can cope with data when there is no clear functional form between the response and the covariates. P-splines are low rank smoothers, (the size of the basis is generally smaller than the dimension of the data), and the number of knots and their location is less important due to the penalty. In addition, they can be represented as mixed effects models (or generalized linear mixed models), so well-known theory and software can be applied. A very interesting property of P-splines is that they do not show boundary effects, i.e. they do not bend towards zero when they are spread outside of the domain of the data. This is very important for forecasting purposes, where the trend is extrapolated. The reader is referred to Currie et al.,13 for an example in the pensions and insurance industry, and Ugarte et al.,14 for a small area problem in the real estate market. P-splines have been recently incorporated to the disease mapping toolkit. Lee and Durbán15 use P-splines to smooth risk in a spatial context, and Ugarte et al.16 derive a three-dimensional space–time P-spline model. The goal here is to extend this last model to forecast risks in future years. The prediction mean squared error (MSE) of the forecast values, as well as an estimator of that quantity, are derived to build prediction intervals. Finally, predicted counts are obtained by multiplying the forecast risks by projections of expected cases based on population data or on projections of population data. The methodology is used to analyze prostate cancer mortality data for all the Spanish provinces in the period 1975–2008 with a focus on cancer mortality forecasting in 2009–2011.

The rest of the article is organized as follows. In Section 2, the spatio-temporal P-spline model is reviewed. Section 3 describes the forecasting approach. The prediction MSE of the log-risk predictor for the forecast values is provided in Section 4. Section 5 illustrates the techniques with the analysis of prostate cancer mortality data from Spain. The article ends with a discussion.

sec.title: 2 Spatio-temporal P-spline model
sec.p: In this section, the space–time interaction model derived by Ugarte et al.16 is briefly reviewed. It will be used to forecast mortality risks and to predict mortality counts for each regions using population projections.

Let Cit denote the number of deaths in region i = 1, … , n and time period t = 1, … , T. Conditional on the relative risks rit, the number of counts is supposed to follow a Poisson distribution with mean μit = eitrit, i.e. (1)Cit|rit~Poisson(μit=eitrit), logμit=logeit+logrit where eit is the expected number of deaths. Then, log rit is modelled as a smooth function of space and time as follows (2)uit=logrit=f(x1i,x2i,x3t)=Bitθ where x1i and x2i are the coordinates of the centroid of the ith small area (longitude and latitude, respectively), x3t is the time, and Bit is the row of the B-spline basis corresponding to the ith area at time t. The B-spline basis is defined as B = B3 ⊗ Bs = B3 ⊗ (B2□B1), with B1, B2, and B3 the marginal bases for longitude, latitude, and time of dimension n × c1, n × c2, and T × c3 respectively, and □ represents the ‘row-wise’ Kronecker product defined by Eilers et al.17 Smoothness is achieved by placing penalties on the coefficients θ. The penalty matrix for three-dimensional data is given by P = λ1 Ic3 ⊗ Ic2 ⊗ P1 + λ2 Ic3 ⊗ P2 ⊗ Ic1 + λ3 P3 ⊗ Ic2 ⊗ Ic1 (see, for example, Currie et al.18), where for i = 1, 2, 3, Pi=Di'Di are the penalties for the marginal bases defined in terms of difference matrices Di,12 Ici are the identity matrices of dimension ci × ci, and λi are the smoothing parameters.

One of the main advantages of P-splines is that they can be represented as linear mixed models (generalized linear mixed models here) using an appropriate transformation matrix T = [Tn, Ts]. Hence, Model (2) can be expressed in matrix form as (3)u=Bθ=Xβ+Zα, α~N(0,G)
Detailed expressions of the penalty and difference matrices Pi and Di, the transformation matrix T = [Tn, Ts], the model matrices X and Z, and the covariance matrix G can be found in Ugarte et al.16

Once Model (2) is expressed as a generalized linear mixed model, penalized quasi-likelihood19 is considered for model estimation. The technique proceeds using an appropriate working vector20 and the REML equations21 under the normal theory linear model.

sec.title: 3 Forecasting
sec.p: In this section, forecast values of the risks are derived using the mixed model reformulation of the P-spline model (see (3)). Suppose we need to forecast p new risk values in each region. Then, the predicted values in the ith small area at a future year t are uit*=log(rit*)=xit*β+zit*α* t=T+1,T+2,…,T+p

The key point to forecast new values is to find explicit expressions for xit*, zit* and to give an estimator for α*. Ugarte et al.14 provide expressions for these matrices in a longitudinal framework, but here the spatial component has to be taken into account. The procedure is based on an extension of the marginal B-spline basis for time. This extended B-spline matrix, denoted as B3*, and the corresponding extended spatio-temporal B-spline matrix B* are given by B3*=(B30B31B32), B*=(B3⊗(B2□B1)0B31⊗(B2□B1)B32⊗(B2□B1))

Note that together, B31 and B32 are the rows of the B-spline matrix for time corresponding to the extended data. Enlarging the range of the time covariate leads to an increase of the number of coefficients to be estimated and hence, the difference matrix D3 and the marginal penalty matrix P3 have to be extended accordingly. Namely D3*=(D30E3F3), P3*=D3*'D3*=(D3'D3+E3'E3E3'F3F3'E3F3'F3)

Here, E3 and F3 are the rows of the new difference matrix necessary to obtain the penalty for the future years. This leads to a new extended penalty matrix P* P*=λ1Ic3*⊗Ic2⊗P1+λ2Ic3*⊗P2⊗Ic1+λ3P3*⊗Ic2⊗Ic1 where Ic3*=(Ic3000).

To reformulate the extended P-spline model as a generalized linear mixed model, an extended transformation matrix is needed. This matrix has to preserve the original transformation T used to fit the data. We then consider T*=(T00F3-1⊗Ic2⊗Ic1)

Therefore, the fixed and random effect matrices of the extended generalized linear mixed model are given by B*T* leading to (4)B*T*=(XZ0X*Z1*Z2*) where X*=X3*⊗(X2□X1),Z1*=[Z3*⊗(X2□X1):X3*⊗(Z2□X1:X2□Z1): Z3*⊗(Z2□X1:X2□Z1):(X3*:Z3*)⊗(Z2□Z1)],Z2*=B32F3-1⊗(B2□B1) Z3* = B31U3s, U3s is a matrix of eigenvectors corresponding to non-zero eigenvalues from the singular value decomposition of the marginal penalty P3, and X3* = [1 : x3*]. Here x3* = (T + 1, T + 2, … , T + p). Using these results, the extended generalized linear mixed model is (uu*)=(XX*)β+(Z0Z1*Z2*)(αα*) where u* are the log risks to be forecast. To provide an estimator of the log-relative risk for the future years, the covariance matrix C of the random effects corresponding to the observed and predicted data is needed. Using the transformation T*, this covariance matrix is given by (5)C=Cov(α,α*)=(GGopGpoGpp)=(G-GTs'(E3'⊗Is)-(E3⊗Is)TsGI*+I*(E3⊗Is)TsGTs'(E3'⊗Is)I*) where Is = Ic2 ⊗ Ic1, I* = Ir ⊗ Is, and Ir is the identity matrix of dimension r × r where r is the number of columns of F3. Using results in Gilmour et al.,22 an estimator for α* is α*∧=GpoG-1α∧=-(E3⊗Is)TsGG-1α∧=-(E3⊗Is)Tsα∧

Finally, the log-risk estimator for oncoming years is given by (6)u∧*=X*β∧+Z1*∧α+Z2*α*∧=X*β∧+(Z1*-Z2*(E3⊗Is)Ts)α∧=X*β∧+Z*Rα∧ where Z*=[Z1*:Z2*], R=(Ir1-(E3⊗Is)Ts), and r1 is the number of columns of Z1*.

sec.title: 4 Mean squared error
sec.p: The MSE estimator of the log-risk predictor (corresponding to the observed data) obtained from the P-spline model considered here has been obtained by Ugarte et al.16 In this section, the prediction mean squared error for the forecast log risks is derived. It is given by (7)MSE[u∧it*(λ)]=E[(u∧it*(λ)-uit*)2]=E[(u∧it*(λ)-u~it*(λ))2]+E[(u~it*(λ)-uit*)2] where u~it*(λ) is the predictor of uit* assuming that the variance components are known, and u∧it*(λ) is the corresponding predictor when the variance parameters are unknown. It can be shown (see the Appendix for details) that E[(u~it*(λ)-uit*)2]=g1it*(λ)+g2it*(λ),E[(u∧it*(λ)-u~it*(λ))2]≈g3it*(λ) where (8)g1it*(λ)=zit*(C-MZ'V-1ZM')zit*',g2it*(λ)=(xit*-zit*MZ'V-1X)(X'V-1X)-1(xit*-zit*MZ'V-1X)',g3it*(λ)=tr[S*VS*'I-1] where C is given by equation (5), M=(G-(E3⊗Is)TsG), S* is a matrix with rows Sj*=zit*(∂M∂λjZ'V-1+MZ'∂V-1∂λj), j=1,2,3, and ℐ−1 is the asymptotic variance of the variance components arising from the PQL estimation procedure. Similar to the mean square error estimator of the fitted log risks, an estimator for the MSE of the forecast log risks is given by MSE∧[u∧it*(λ)]=g1it*(λ∧)+g2it*(λ∧)+2g3it*(λ∧) where the terms g1it*(λ∧), g2it*(λ∧), and g3it*(λ∧) are obtained by plugging in the REML estimator of λ into expressions (8).

sec.title: 5 Illustration
sec.p: In this section, prostate cancer mortality data in 50 Spanish provinces (excluding Ceuta and Melilla) over the period 1975–2008 are used to illustrate the methodology developed in the previous sections with a focus on mortality risks and counts forecasting. The evolution of cancer mortality risks is complex and varies among the different regions in Spain. Several factors could explain these differences: the quality of the population-based mortality registers, the differences in access to systematic health proofs, and the dissimilarity in health assistance. This divergence among regions makes necessary to split Spain into provinces to better analyze the evolution of geographical patterns of prostate cancer mortality risks and to forecast both mortality risks and counts. Prostate cancer is the third most common cause of cancer mortality in Spanish males, after lung and colorectal cancer, with about 5000 deaths each year. According to data from the Spanish National Epidemiology Center, in the year 2002, prostate cancer mortality rate was 29.31 per 100,000 inhabitants, and an adjusted rate (standard European population) of 21.48 cases per 100,000 inhabitants. A total of 150,616 prostate cancer deaths were registered from 1975 to 2008 in Spain. Data on Spanish population and deaths were obtained from records of the Spanish Statistical Institute. Expected counts are calculated on the basis of age-specific mortality rates for Spain during the whole period and the age-specific population at risk for each year. The number of expected counts per area and per year ranges from 13.76 to 794.14 while the number of observed cases varies from 6 to 651. The coordinates (longitude and latitude) of the centroids of the provinces and time are considered explanatory variables. The B-splines bases have been set up once the number of (equidistant) internal knots, the degree of the B-spline, and the order of the penalty are defined. In this case, 11 knots for both spatial dimensions, and 9 knots for time are considered according to the rule by Ruppert.23 Cubic B-splines and a second-order penalty have been established. Then, the spatial bases B1 and B2 are of dimension 50 × 13, and B3 has dimension 34 × 11.

The main focus of this article is on predicting risks and mortality cases for future years. In particular, we are interested in predicting cases up to 3 years as there is usually a delay of 3 years to have mortality registries available. Predicted counts are obtained by multiplying the forecast risks by projections of expected cases based on projections of population data. Figure 1 displays maps of estimated relative risks from 1975 to 2008 and forecast relative risks from 2009 to 2011 for the 50 Spanish provinces (a map of the provinces is provided in Figure 5 in an online appendix for clarification purposes). Prostate cancer exhibits an increasing trend between 1975 and 1999, being the northern provinces those that experienced a higher risk increase. From year 2000 onward, a risk decrease is observed in all the regions as the maps are getting lighter and lighter. The forecast risks reveal that this decreasing trend continues from 2009 to 2011. Temporal trends from 1975 to 2008 are displayed in Figure 2 for six selected provinces located in different parts of Spain (North, Central Spain, Mediterranean area and South). For each region the standard mortality ratios (non-smooth lines), the fitted risks (smooth lines), and their 95% confidence bands are shown. Forecast risks for the period 2009–2011 are also provided together with the corresponding 95% prediction band. It can be observed that in high populated areas, such as Valencia or Sevilla, the smooth trend follows the standardized mortality ratio very well. However, in low populated areas (Soria or Segovia), the effect of smoothing is strong. This is desirable as the standardized mortality ratios are very unstable. Figure 1.
Maps of smooth relative risk from 1975 to 2008. Maps for the period 2009–2011 display forecast risks for the Spanish provinces. Figure 2.
Smooth temporal risk trends and confidence bands from 1975 to 2008 together with forecast risks and prediction bands for the period 2009–2011 for six selected provinces.

Although not shown here to conserve space, trends for all the provinces have been plotted (see Figure 6 in the online appendix). Three diverging trends have been observed in the first half of the period among provinces. While in most provinces trends have stable or rising behavior, in provinces such as Murcia, Badajoz, Albacete, Huelva, Sevilla, Cádiz and Málaga, a falling trend has been observed. The scenario in the second half of the period is more homogenous. A decreasing trend is observed in all the provinces. Interestingly, the risk in provinces like Córdoba, Jaén and Granada is smaller than the overall risk in Spain in the entire period. Finally, a decrease in prostate cancer mortality is predicted in all Spanish provinces for the period 2009–2011. Similar results were obtained when analyzing these data with an ANOVA type P-spline model.24 However, risk predictions were not provided with this model. Using the forecast relative risks for years 2009, 2010 and 2011, predicted counts of prostate mortality are obtained by multiplying the forecast relative risk by the number of expected counts calculated using projections of population for those years. Confidence intervals are obtained by multiplying the lower and upper bounds of the intervals for the relative risks by the number of expected counts. Table 2 in the online appendix displays the predicted number of cases and the confidence intervals for the years 2009–2011 in all Spanish provinces. The observed counts in 2008 are also displayed for comparison purposes.

sec.title: 5.1 Validation
sec.p: In this section, the predictive performance of the spatio-temporal model is assessed. Three-year-ahead predictions of mortality counts for prostate cancer in the Spanish provinces have been calculated. They have been generated for K = 14 years, 1995–2008, based on data from 1975 onward. That is, predictions for 1995 were based on data from 1975 to 1992; predictions for 1996 were based on data from 1975 to 1993 and so on (similarly as in Ghosh and Tiwari7). For evaluation purposes, 2 and 1-year-ahead predictions have been similarly calculated. To asses the predictive ability of the model the following measures have been calculated for each province. Namely, the absolute relative bias (ARB), and the relative root mean prediction error (RRMPE) given by ARBi=1 14∑t=19952008|C∧it-CitCit|, i=1,…,50RRMPEi=1 14∑t=19952008(C∧it-CitCit)2, i=1,…,50.

Finally, to summarize results, the mean absolute relative bias (MARB) and the mean relative root mean prediction error (MRRPE) have been considered MARB=1 50∑i=150ARBi, MRRMPE=1 50∑i=150RRMPEi. Table 1 displays these indicators for 3-, 2- and 1-year-ahead predictions together with coverage probabilities (95% nominal value) for the predicted counts. As suggested by one referee, P-spline models for each province have been fitted separately with time as the explanatory variable to see if the spatio-temporal model (3) produces better results. Table 1.
MARB and MRRMPE and 95% coverage probabilities for three, two, and one year ahead predictions for the spatio-temporal P-spline model and univariate temporal P-spline models
Spatio-temporal P-spline model (2) Univariate temporal P-spline model
MARB MRRMPE 95%-Cover. MARB MRRMPE 95%-Cover.
Three-year-ahead 0.138 0.177 80.860 0.170 0.216 57.000
Two-year-ahead 0.124 0.159 70.430 0.147 0.185 57.000
One-year-ahead 0.116 0.149 58.000 0.129 0.163 57.140

The MARB and the MRRMPE are a bit larger for 3-year-ahead predictions as expected. These quantities are higher for the univariate model indicating that the spatio-temporal model provides better predictions. For the spatio-temporal P-spline model, the MARB is around 14% for 3-year-ahead predictions while this quantity takes the value 17% for the univariate temporal P-spline model. The MARB becomes smaller for 2- and 1-year-ahead predictions being the values for the univariate model higher than the values of the spatio-temporal model. A similar pattern is observed with the MRRMPE. The highest coverage rates for the spatio-temporal model are obtained for 3-year-ahead predictions because the prediction error increases as we move away from the last observed year. The coverage rates obtained with the univariate model are smaller, though the difference is reduced for one year ahead predictions. This seems reasonable because the differences in MARB and MRRMPE for 1-year-ahead predictions between the spatio-temporal and the univariate models are also reduced. Overall, a better performance of the spatio-temporal model is expected as we borrow strength from space and time, while the univariate P-spline models only consider data from one province.

Figure 3 displays the observed mortality counts (dots) of prostate cancer in six provinces (Coruña, Guipuzcoa, Soria, Segovia, Valencia and Sevilla) from 1995 to 2008 (the validation period). These provinces were selected to represent the diversity of Spanish geography and population. While Soria and Segovia are low populated provinces, Valencia and Sevilla have more inhabitants. The 3-year-ahead predicted number of cases obtained with the spatio-temporal P-spline model (crosses connected with lines) and prediction intervals (vertical lines) are also shown to assess how the predicted number of cases tracks the true observed ones. It is clear from the picture that the model provides reasonable predictions. This agrees with the results shown in Table 1. Note that Soria and Segovia are scarcely populated and hence the coverage rates are rather poor. The same graphs for all the Spanish provinces can be found in Figure 7 in an online appendix. Figure 4 displays observed versus 3-year-ahead predicted counts for the period 1995–2008 and all the provinces. Most of the points are close to the main diagonal, indicating that the model performance is sensible. It seems that in the range 500–600 predictions are more variable. These points correspond to the provinces of Madrid and Barcelona, where population changes and mortality cases variability are expected to be larger than in other regions. Figure 3.
Observed (dots) and forecast (crosses) prostate cancer mortality counts in six Spanish provinces during the validation period (1995–2008). Vertical lines represents 95% prediction intervals. Figure 4.
Observed vs. forecast prostate cancer mortality counts in the evaluation period (1995–2008) and in all Spanish provinces.

sec.title: 6 Discussion
sec.p: Population-based cancer statistics are crucial for health planners, policy makers, and cancer information providers to prioritize investments in cancer control and prevention. However, data on cancer mortality are usually available to the general public after approximately 3 years due to administrative and procedural delays. This means that cancer data till 2008 are available in 2011, and then, there is a gap between the present time and the data available. Consequently, it is sensible to provide predictions based on statistical models. This is particularly important nowadays because the health system in many countries is suffering from a shortage in budget due to the economic crisis. In this article, a spatio-temporal P-spline model with space–time interactions is considered for smoothing and forecasting. The methodology relies on an extension of the marginal B-spline basis for time to include future years. The penalty matrix is accordingly modified, and an extended transformation matrix preserving the original one is used to reformulate the P-spline model as a generalized linear mixed model. The MSE of the log-risk estimator of the future risks is provided and prediction intervals are built. Finally, mortality cases are predicted by multiplying the forecast risk by the expected number of counts calculated from projections of population data. To asses the predictive quality of the model, prostate cancer mortality counts over the period 1975–2008 have been used. More precisely, 3-, 2-, and 1-year-ahead count predictions for years 1995–2008 have been compared with the observed counts. Mean absolute relative bias and mean relative root mean prediction error have been calculated revealing a good performance of the model. Coverage rates at 95% nominal value for the predicted counts have been also provided indicating a reasonable coverage for 3-year-ahead predictions. However, caution is recommended with prediction intervals as higher rates are related to wider, and hence less informative intervals. As suggested by one referee, we have considered other spline bases (thin plate splines) and a third-order penalty. Results show that the smooth trends for the observed data remain practically unchanged while predictions are a bit worse (in terms of MARB and MRRMPE) when using different bases and a third-order penalty. Finally, we would like to emphasize that the spatio-temporal model with space time interactions provides better results than the individual models fitted to each province separately. This means that it is important to consider spatial dependence as well as space time interactions to make future risk predictions. A possible limitation of forecasting mortality counts are the population projections. As censuses are usually available every 10 years, projections could be more questionable as we move away from the census year. Summarizing, in this article a flexible approach to forecast cancer mortality risks and their prediction intervals is developed. The model can be used with other cancers and long-latency diseases, or even in economic contexts. A conclusion of public health relevance is that the forecast horizon suggests a decline in prostate cancer mortality in all the Spanish provinces within the oncoming years.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank Marina Pollán from the National Epidemiology Center (area of Environmental Epidemiology and Cancer) for providing the data.

UgarteMDGoicoaTEtxeberriaJA P-spline ANOVA type model in space-time disease mapping. Stoch Environ Res Risk Assess (in press). 2012; DOI 10.1007/s00477-012-0570-4.
PrasadNGNRaoJNKThe estimation of mean squared error of small area estimators. J Am Stat Assoc 1990; 85: 163–171.

sec.title: Appendix
sec.p: In this section, expressions g1*, g2*, and g3* corresponding to the MSE of the log-risk predictor for future years are derived. Recall that the MSE is expressed as MSE[u∧it*(λ)]=E[(u∧it*(λ)-uit*)2]=E[(u∧it*(λ)-u~it*(λ))2]+E[(u~it*(λ)-uit*)2], where u~it*(λ) is the predictor of uit* assuming the the variance components are known, and u∧it*(λ) is the corresponding predictor when the variance parameters are unknown. In this section, the explicit expressions of E[(u∧it*(λ)-u~it*(λ))2] and E[(u~it*(λ)-uit*)2] terms are obtained.

We first compute u~it*(λ)-uit*. u~it*(λ)-uit*=(xit*β~+zit*1~α+zit*2α~*)-(xit*β+zit*1α+zit*2α*)=xit*β~+(zit*1:zit*2)(~αα*~)-xit*β+(zit*1:zit*2)(αα*)=xit*β~+(zit*1:zit*2)(GZ'V-1(Y-Xβ~)-(E3⊗Is)TsGZ'V-1(Y-Xβ~))-xit*β+(zit*1:zit*2)(αα*)=xit*β~+(zit*1:zit*2)(G-(E3⊗Is)TsG)Z'V-1(Y-Xβ~)-xit*β+(zit*1:zit*2)ξ=qit*(β~-β)+zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ), where zit*=(zit*1:zit*2), M is defined in Section 4, qit*=(xit*-zit*MZ'V-1X), and ξ=(αα*).
Next, it is shown that Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ)) = 0. Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ) =Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*MZ'V-1Y)︸[A]-Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*MZ'V-1Xβ)︸[B]-Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*ξ)︸[C]
Let us calculate [A]. Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*MZ'V-1Y)=Cov(qit*β~,zit*MZ'V-1Y)=qit*(X'V-1X)-1X'V-1Var(Y)V-1ZM'zit*'=qit*(X'V-1X)-1X'V-1ZM'zit*'.
The expression [B] is equal to zero Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*MZ'V-1Xβ)=0.
Finally, expression [C] Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*ξ)=Cov(qit*β~,zit*ξ)=Cov(qit*(X'V-1X)-1X'V-1Y,zit*ξ)=qit*(X'V-1X)-1X'V-1Cov(Y,ξ)zit*'=qit*(X'V-1X)-1X'V-1ZM'zit*', where Cov(Y, ξ) = ZM′.
Then Cov(qit*(β~-β),zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ)) = [A]−[B]−[C] = 0, and hence E[(u~it*(λ)-uit*)2]=Var(u~it*(λ)-uit*)=Var(qit*(β~-β))︸[D]+Var(zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ))︸[E]
The term [D] is calculated as Var(qit*(β~-β))=qit*Var(β~)qit*'=qit*(X'V-1X)-1qit*':=g2it*(λ).

The term [E] is expressed as Var(zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ))=Var(zit*MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ))︸[E1] +Var(zit*ξ)︸[E2] -2Cov(zit*MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ),zit*ξ)︸[E3]. [E1] is calculated as Var(zit*MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ))=zit*MZ'V-1Var(Y)V-1ZM'zit*'=zit*MZ'V-1ZM'zit*'
Now, [E2] is given by Var(zit*ξ)=zit*Czit*', where C is given by equation (5) in Section 3, and finally, [E3] is calculated as Cov(zit*MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ),zit*ξ)=zit*MZ'V-1Cov(Y,ξ)zit*'=zit*MZ'V-1ZM'zit*'
Therefore, Var(zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ))=zit*MZ'V-1ZM'zit*'+zit*Czit*'-2zit*MZ'V-1ZM'zit*'=zit*(C-MZ'V-1ZM')zit*':=g1it*(λ).
From [D] and [E] E[(u~it*(λ)-uit*)2]=Var(u~it*(λ)-uit*)=Var(qit*(β~-β))+Var(zit*(MZ'V-1(Y-Xβ)-ξ))=qit*(X'V-1X)-1)qit*'+zit*(C-MZ'V-1ZM')zit*'=g2it*(λ)+g1it*(λ).

Finally, let us compute the term E[(u∧it*(λ)-u~it*(λ))2]. Following results in Prasad and Rao25 E[(u∧it*(λ)-u~it*(λ))2]≈tr[S*VS*'I-1]:=g3it*(λ), where S* is a matrix with rows Sj*=z*it(∂M∂λjZ'V-1+MZ'∂V-1∂λj), j=1,2,3 where, ∂M∂λj=(∂G∂λj-(E3⊗Is)Ts∂G∂λj) and ∂G∂λj=∂F-1∂λj=-F-1∂F∂λjF-1; ∂V-1∂λj=-V-1∂V∂λjV-1=V-1ZF-1∂F∂λjF-1Z'V-1.
Putting all the results together, MSE[u∧it*(λ)]=g1it*(λ)+g2it*(λ)+g3it*(λ), and an estimator is given by MSE∧[u∧it*(λ)]=g1it*(λ∧)+g2it*(λ∧)+2g3it*(λ∧).
